subject: The simplest thing that could possibly work. WAS: [junit] Test-friendly, but not caller-friendly?

messageBody:
Hi all,

On 8/16/06, Cédric Beust ♔ <cbeust@...> wrote:
> But your reaction proves the point I was making earlier even better than I
> could have: where do you draw the line when you are trying to "do the
> simplest thing that could possibly work"?

That is an interesting question. I think what the simplest thing that
could possibly work is often subjective. I think the answer depends on
who is implementing the solution and the "tools" in that persons
"mental toolbox".
Sometimes the simplest thing that could possibly work, as pointed out
by my better half, is interpreted as "the easiest thing that could
possibly work". They are not always the same. Years ago I often heard
statements like:
"Sure polymorphism is cool but swicth clauses are much easie to
understand for most people"

So,

for some people, when developing a robot, this:

executeCommand(Command command) {
switch (command.type) {
case Command.GETLAUNDRY :
getLaundry(); break;
case Command.DODISHES :
doDishes(); break;
case Command.CLEANHOUSE :
cleanHouse(); break;
default
throw new UnknownCommandException(command);
}
}

is easier and thus simpler than

executeCommand(Command command) {
command.execute();
}

For others alternative 2 (of course with one new class for each
command) is simpler and easier.

How do you use the rule "the simplest thing that could possibly work?"
I think it is hard to argue witht someone else that "this is simpler
than that" but you can keep /yourself/ from doing things in a more
complicated manner than absolutely necessary.

I think I abuse interfaces according to some people but I find it
simpler because they communicate clearly what I intend the /published/
interface of my code to be. To me it is simpler to be able to ignore
implementation specific stuff by just looking at the interfaces.

So what is "simple" to you?
